The former Congressional Correspondence and Quality Review Branch under the Office of Legislative Affairs is now part of the Executive Secretariat Correspondence Office (ESCO) under the Office of the Executive Secretariat. As a result of this organizational change, guidance previously included in IRM 11.5.3, Guide to Congressional Correspondence, and Document 11426, the IRS Correspondence Manual (September 2011) was combined into a revised IRM 1.10.1, IRS Correspondence Manual. The IRM 11.5.3 and Document 11426 are obsolete.

The ESCO is responsible for assigning, monitoring, and reviewing all ESCO controlled correspondence addressed to the Treasury Secretary, IRS Commissioner, Deputy Commissioners, and the Director, Legislative Affairs. For additional information send inquiries to the ESCO mailbox visit the ESCO website at http://irweb.irs.gov/AboutIRS/bu/cos/execsec/default.aspx.
This revision to IRM 1.10.1 replaces Document 11426, The IRS Correspondence Manual guidance previously covered in IRM 11.5.3, Guide to Congressional Correspondence.

) As a result of organizational changes, this IRM reflects the change from Legislative Affairs, Congressional Correspondence and Quality Review Branch to Office of the Executive Executive Secretariat Correspondence Office.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This supersedes Document 11426, IRS Correspondence Manual, dated September 2011. This also supersedes IRM 11.5.3, obsolesced on August 12, 2014.

) Purpose: The IRS Correspondence Manual defines policy and procedures preparing IRS and Department of the Treasury correspondence. The dures in this manual govern all Executive Secretariat Correspondence (ESCO) controlled correspondence. In addition, IRM

provides guidance for all other IRS correspondence generated for internal and communication, except for letters generated by the Correspondence and Computer Paragraph (CP) Notices. Letters with approved form (computer-generated) are also exempt. Overall, the IRS Correspondence Manual provides guidance and procedures consistent with the Department the Treasury’s correspondence procedures. (
) Audience: Employees who prepare executive correspondence. In addition, IRM
audience also includes e-Trak coordinators who use the e-Trak system a communications tracking tool, to process ESCO controlled corre- spondence. (
) Program Owner: The Office of the Executive Secretariat, under the Chief of Staff office, is responsible for the contents of IRM
and any updates. (

) Responsibility: The ESCO also receives correspondence addressed to the President of the United States; and referrals from Treasury Legislative and Treasury Executive Secretariat. Operating as a national headquarters section, ESCO: a. Reviews incoming congressional and taxpayer correspondence. Also reviews employee inquiries addressed to the Commissioner. b. Controls the correspondence in the communications and tracking e-Trak. c. Assigns the correspondence to the business units (BU) for response. d. Reviews the draft responses to congressional members, key IRS holders, some taxpayer inquiries and employee inquiries. e. Monitors BU actions to respond to the inquiries. (

) Most Executive Secretariat Correspondence Office (ESCO) controlled corre- spondence requires a written response. (

) For letters to members of Congress, usually we respond directly to the member either at the Washington, DC office or a local office, as the specifies in his or her cover letter unless it would create a disclosure issue. Without proper disclosure authorization, we must respond directly to the taxpayer with a cover letter to the member of Congress. (

) If the member asks us to reply directly to his or her constituent, we do so send a cover letter with a copy of our response to the member of Congress (provided we have proper disclosure authorization.) (

) The Executive Secretariat Correspondence Office (ESCO) closely monitors controls designated “Commissioner Correspondence.” These include letters requiring the signature of the Treasury Secretary, IRS Commissioner, IRS Deputy Commissioner, or IRS Operating Division (OD) Commissioner. The ESCO will note the signature level in the topic field of the control. (

) Commissioner letters are from key members of the Congress or committees of interest to the IRS. They may also be letters from any on topics of special interest to the Commissioner. The ESCO includes dures for handling these controls in the “Special Instructions” field of the control. The “Commissioner” designation appears in the topic field. (

) The Commissioner usually signs letters to the members of any committee when they write in their capacity as chair on committee letterhead. The missioner also signs letters to ranking members when they write in their capacity as ranking members on committee letterhead. (

) The Executive Secretariat Correspondence Office (ESCO) monitors and reviews responses to Commissioner Email Inquiries (CEI). This type of spondence includes employee inquiries and suggestions that employees directly to the *Commissioner email box. The Director, Executive Secretariat and the Chief of Staff’s office will designate some cases as “Commissioner Priority.” These cases are inquiries that the Commissioner is particularly ested in and would like to see an immediate resolution or investigation. (

) Some CEIs may require response and input from two or more business (BU), also called dual assignment responses. When this occurs, ESCO will assign each employee issue to the appropriate BU for response and each case in e-Trak. Once ESCO receives the final approved draft, ESCO send the response to the employee and inform the employee that he or she can expect to receive a response to the other issue(s) in a future email. (

) Signature Level: ESCO will return the response to the employee using the Commissioner’s email box. If the BU decides the response should come directly from the BU, they should contact ESCO. Additionally, ESCO may the BU to send a response to the employee, especially responses about sensitive issues. (

) The Executive Secretariat Correspondence Office (ESCO) monitors and reviews responses to Commissioner field visit (CFV) inquiries. The CFVs employee inquiries and suggestions that the Commissioner and his staff receive during field visits and tours to various IRS locations where participate in events such as town hall meetings, luncheons, and manager NTEU meetings. The subject matter experts (analysts) in the business units (BUs) draft these responses and submit them for review to ESCO. (

) Since a number of the CFV inquiries come from employees during town hall meetings, we may not have an employee name to associate with the case. a. If an employee’s name is not included in the control, the BU analyst a response addressing the issues and emails it to the ESCO mailbox at *Executive Secretariat E-Review. b. If an employee’s name is included in the control, the BU analyst must a response addressed to the employee at his or her work address. (
) The ESCO will send a wrap-up letter to the site coordinator representative (SCR) summarizing the responses to all of the employee inquiries after Commissioner visit. (
) You must clear all draft responses through ESCO. Please email your draft response for review
business days before the e-Trak target date to the *Executive Secretariat E-Review mailbox. (

) Signature Level: If a name and address are available, ESCO will send the response to the employee from the Commissioner’s mailbox. The ESCO will send the CFV responses without an addressee to the senior commissioner representative (SCR).

The Executive Secretariat Correspondence Office (ESCO) monitors and reviews responses to Commissioner field visit (CFV) inquiries. The CFVs are employee inquiries and suggestions that the Commissioner and his staff receive during field visits and tours to various IRS locations where employees participate in events such as town hall meetings, luncheons, and manager and NTEU meetings. The subject matter experts (analysts) in the business units (BUs) draft these responses and submit them for review to ESCO.
Since a number of the CFV inquiries come from employees during town hall meetings, we may not have an employee name to associate with the case.
